Student statement: Web applications are vulnerable and what we can do about it to protect from that. Some web application vulnerabilities are: authentication, XSS (cross-site scripting), DDoS, weak past.

If the code is not well implemented, there may be problems with authentication. For example if the application stores passwords as plain text in the database without cryptography this increases the likelihood that someone who enters the database can log in as an admin and delete all data. To avoid such a problem, it is necessary to hash the password. It would also be desirable to use salting in addition to hashing also adds random characters. Some examples of hash algorithms are: SHA256, SHA512, etc.

In this case, the attacker stores the code (usually in Javascript) in the database where later renders that code using a web application. It means when a user visits the web page the code will start executing. In this way, we can access confidential user data data, i.e. one can steal a user's session and thus access it private data in the application even though we do not have its password. One of the simplest the method of protection against XSS attacks is to set the browser's security level to the highest level. This way no XSS code can be run.

A DDoS attack occurs when an attacker sends a lot of requests to a server with the aim of overload the page or shut down completely. These attacks can last for days, or even longer. 2DDoS can be prevented in several ways, namely: blocking all traffic from a certain countries until a defense mechanism is made. Another way is to block them certain IP addresses. The third way and perhaps the safest is to buy some kind of DDoS protection (Cloudflare is popular).

If the user sets a weak password with few digits, it can be quite difficult for the attacker simply to log into the user account. For example there is a brute force method which it tries all possible combinations depending on the number of digits in the code. Also every page today offers the option "Forgot your password?" where we can respond to some secret question, for example, "In which city were you born?". This is where "dictionary attack" comes in handy. where a text file with a list of all cities in Croatia is used and in that way answer correctly in a few seconds and set the password again.

SQL security vulnerability of a web application where an attacker tries to use the application code to access or damage the database. If successful, it enables the attacker creating, reading, updating, modifying or deleting data stored in the database.

SQL injection is one of the most common types of web application security vulnerabilities. SQL injection usually occurs when the user is prompted for input (eg username), a instead of a name, the user provides an SQL statement that will unknowingly be run in the database.

Some tools that test web application vulnerabilities are: Nikto, Wapiti, Pentest-Tools, etc. There are also some tools in Kali Linux for testing web applications, namely: nmap (for server status detection), WackoPicko (for testing source code), DirBuster (for finding files and directories on a web server) etc.

The word private indicates that these are resources that are reserved only for us. Memory, processing power and data are not shared with other users. In this case, "virtual" means that it is a partition on a physical server, which is dedicated to you.
VPS hosting is cheaper than a full dedicated hosting plan that uses a physical server.
Many VPS plans can be customized as needed, so you pay for what you want, but don't have to deal with any features you'll never need.

Although resources are still shared, as with the time-sharing model, virtualization provides a higher level of security, depending on the type of virtualization used, because individual virtual servers are largely isolated from each other and can run their own full-fledged operating systems that can be independently restarted as virtual instance.
It is used to reduce hardware costs by condensing failover clusters onto a single machine, which dramatically reduces costs while providing the same services.

It is necessary to test new programs in an independent server environment. Dedicated servers are often too expensive for sporadic use. Instead, users prefer a VPS environment. They are cheap enough to have on hand and flexible enough to test any application.

When you store and share large or complex files, sometimes it's best to store them virtually so as not to burden your regular systems. A VPS is the perfect solution for storing large files while keeping them available when needed.
As one of the most popular reasons for VPS hosting, VPNs are easy to create, use, and even resell to other users. VPN users prefer virtual private servers because they are cheap and secure.
Virtual private servers are also used as a proxy to hide the user's IP address. In this way, VPS clients add an extra layer of security between their local computer and the servers they access.
VPS solutions are great for making copies of web pages and files that you make changes to or that might get damaged at some point.

Basically you can use a VPS for anything you would use a dedicated server for; however, keep in mind that you'll get less overall storage and bandwidth. If you don't need an entire dedicated server, VPS is a more affordable choice because you'll only pay for what you need.

The advantage of VPS is that you don't have to worry about hardware management - so you don't need to monitor the status of hard drives, RAM and CPU. They are adapted to host most types of web projects of moderate dimensions.
VPS hosting isn't as cheap as shared hosting, but it's cheaper than dedicated hosting because you only pay for what you need. VPS delivers great value for money
Reliable performance-You have your own allocated bandwidth and storage and don't have to share it with other companies
Control-You get SSH and root access to your environment, giving you more control.

Less powerful than dedicated servers. A VPS server can be perfect for personal websites or for heavy programs, but if you plan to run a huge business portal with a huge forum section, that will send tons of emails every day, and that will run all the resource-hungry programs at the same time, you will need a dedicated machine
Requires more technical knowledge. Unlike a cloud web hosting account, a VPS server will require more technical knowledge to manage and maintain.
At its simplest level, virtualization allows you to virtually and cost-effectively have two or more computers with two or more completely different environments on a single piece of hardware.
Adequate installations in the space are required, such as power and network cables, which must be assembled according to special rules in order to avoid operational errors.
The cooling system is also important and must be properly arranged.
All this requires people with certain knowledge who will prepare the place for the servers and finally install them
servers must be maintained, new updates installed, repaired or backed up

The system is scalable and can become very large. The bigger the system, the more engineers are needed for maintenance and customer support. A system can become so large that it contains multiple teams such as a team of people for marketing, operations, maintenance, customer support, etc. As the system expands, more resources and
engineers are needed.

In the future, the system could be evaluated so that the main server is upgraded with resources, and it could be expanded to even more virtual private servers, or more resources would be assigned to them. Let's say that we assign more resources to vps1, then vps1 can host more websites, support larger ones or the like, depending on what kind of upgrade is being done. During the evolution of the system, they could encounter challenges such as a greater number of traffic, i.e. interest in the product and more work related to its management.

Z-Wave works wirelessly and securely. Devices can be easily accessed and controlled remotely on your smartphone, tablet or computer, so you can control your smart home from anywhere in the world! A Z-Wave hub receives commands from you via your smartphone, tablet or computer and routes the command to the destination device.
Compatibility: It is compatible with other devices. All smart household devices will be able to connect to Z-wave and communicate with each other.
Wireless communication: devices can communicate with each other as long as they are within 50-100 ft of each other. Devices can connect to the network without being in range of the router.

Easy setup: It is very easy to set up a wireless network by adding or removing devices without disturbing the router. The ability to easily add other devices to the Zwave network helps in building a home automation system. To set up the device, just follow the instructions in the manual that comes with the device.
Flexibility: Modern Z-wave technology is flexible enough to accommodate some changes to thousands of products. Devices will be able to communicate and work together.
Efficiency: The device has excellent performance and operates at 908.42 MHz; there is no interference with Wi-Fi or 2.4 GHz devices.
Suitability: Z-wave is suitable for small businesses or residential homes. It is great for use in a single building.
Security: Z-wave uses AES-128 encryption to provide a secure network to users
Interpolability: Z-wave allows users to mix and match devices. This gives them complete freedom to decide which devices to connect. Users can customize it uniquely according to their needs.
Range: Due to reduced interference, Z-waves improved range optimized through the device-hopping aspect of the technology.
High transfer rate: Z-wave supports data transfer rates of 9.6 Kbps, 40 Kbps and 100 Kbps. This ensures that devices can communicate with each other.

Signal Transmission: Devices connected to Z-wave must be within 28 m square (300 sq ft). If the size of your space is larger than this, some devices will lose signal transmission data. Some of these devices will not be able to send or receive commands from the central controller, the hub.
Expensive: Compared to other wireless devices, Z-wave is more expensive than some alternative solutions.

Limited nodes: Z-wave limits the number of devices or components connected to it to 232. Zwave is limited to 4 hubs if more than 4 switches are used, then additional switches or nodes will lose signal.

Resource requirements: Z-wave is battery-intensive and consumes more power compared to other wireless technologies, so you need to change the battery more often. This is why the device has a larger size.

Network Security: You must have knowledge on how to maintain network security and prevent unauthorized access to the wired network. Z-wave uses radio frequency transmission and intentional or unintentional interference is possible.
Topology structure: Z-wave only supports tree topology structure.
Communication speed: It relies on a communication speed of up to 100 Kbps compared to the Zigbee standard.
Smart Hub: You must have a controller to manage the network.
Network coverage: if you want to cover a wide area, you need to have more Z-wave devices module to cover that large area.
Closed system: Protocol and software patches can only be done by Z-wave.
Zigbee has a network topology with low cost, multi-purpose data transmission, and is power efficient
It has a very long battery life
Easy to install
Short working period results in energy saving and communication power consumption
Low complexity and low data transfer rate
High maintenance costs, lack of a comprehensive solution and slow materialization
Low throughput, as well as low network stability, are also some of its drawbacks that make it a step backward compared to others
Replacing Zigbee-compatible devices can be expensive
Zigbee is not as secure as a WiFi-based security system

Users: Regular users:They use the social network platform for personal purposes such as keeping in touch with friends and family, sharing updates about their lives, and consuming content shared by others., Content creators:Users actively contribute content to the platforms by posting and sharing, photos and videos, writing articles or creating other forms of media. , Companies:They use the platform to advertise their services.
Publishing and sharing:All users should be able to create and share a variety of content, including posts, images, videos, etc.
Interaction with content:users should be able to interact with other shared content by liking posts, commenting, sharing and replying.
Personalization and referrals:Recommend relevant content, new integrations and current topics on the site to improve the user experience.
Messages and communication:Users should be able to communicate privately with each other via direct messaging or group chat.
Analytics and Insights:Content producers and brands/publishers should have access to analytics tools that provide insight into the performance of their content and campaigns.
User management:manages user registration, profiles and privacy settings to ensure a secure user experience.
Content management:manages the creation, sharing and recommendation of different types of content, including text posts, photos, videos and links.
Interaction management:Facilitates user interaction with content and other users through actions such as liking, commenting, sending messages.
Analytics:provides users, content creators and advertisers with analytical tools to track user engagement metrics and content performance.
Performance:The system should be responsive and able to handle a large amount of concurrent users and content interactions without significant latency.
Scalability:The platform should be designed to scale seamlessly as the user base grows.
Reliability:The system should be highly reliable, with minimal downtime and service interruptions. Users should be able to access the platform at all times.
Security:Security is paramount to protect user data, privacy and platform integrity.
Privacy:Users should be in control of their personal information and the content shared on the platform.
Accessibility:The platform should be accessible to users with disabilities, adhering to accessibility standards and guidelines to ensure equal access and usability for all users.
Customization:Users should be able to customize their experience to their liking, including profile settings, notification settings, and content settings.
Content moderation:The platform should implement effective content moderation mechanisms to detect and remove inappropriate or harmful content.
Improved: content recommendation accuracy by Implement real-time user behavior analysis to improve content recommendation accuracy.
Improved: advertising analytics by using IoT sensors to track user engagement with physical ads in real time.
Improved: Content recommendation by Implementation of a personalized content delivery system based on user preferences and behavior analysis.
Improved: efficiency of content moderation by Introducing content moderation powered by artificial intelligence to automatically detect and remove inappropriate content.
Improved: User engagement metrics by Implementing AR-based interactive ads for improved user engagement.
Improved: Infrastructure scalability by Implementation of server infrastructure with automatic scaling.

Potential users of the system are Citizens, students, pupils, children, pensioners, book administration
librarian, user administration librarian
The user (librarian) initiates the entry of new books into the system.Entry of new books (id, title, author, shelf,)

The system displays a form for entering book information, including ID,
title, author, and shelf position.

The system checks the validity of the entered data and stores it in the
database.
The library inventory is updated with a new book.
The user (librarian) selects the option to delete or replace the book.
The librarian selects the book to be deleted or replaced.
Book search The user enters the search criteria.

The system searches the database and displays results that match the
search criteria.

The user reviews the results and selects the book that suits him. If necessary, the user can get detailed information about the book,
including availability and location on the shelf.
Registration of new users: The system displays a form for entering information about the new user, such as first name, last name, address, contact information, etc.
Issuing a card: After entering a new user, the system generates a card with the necessary user information. The librarian prints the card and hands it to the user.

Renewal of membership: The librarian checks the membership status and the payment of the membership fee.If necessary, the librarian updates the membership information and extends the validity of the card.
Deleting members: The librarian selects the user to delete. The system confirms the deletion of the user and removes it from the database.
Check of borrowed books per user: The librarian enters the user ID. The system displays a list of books that are currently on loan to that user.
Late payment: The librarian checks overdue deadlines and calculates the amount of the delay. The user is issued an invoice for the delay.
Membership verification function for users
Checking the date of borrowing and return

Extending the loan: The system extends the loan period for the selected books, updates the
return dates and informs the user about the new dates.
Price list: The librarian can update or modify the price list as needed.

A library system with the innovations you proposed would be quite extensive,  with many parts and functionalities. By considering the usual aspects of a library, including book and patron administration, adding innovations such as VR books, app-based lending, and a book-finding robot, the size of the system increases significantly. This requires a complex management system and the integration of various technological elements.

Number of required engineers:The number of engineers required to develop such a system depends on various factors such as the scope of the project, the time frame, the technologies used, etc. For such an ambitious project, it is likely to require a larger team of experts that includes programmers, database engineers, user interface designers, virtual reality, etc. I guess there should be at least a few dozen engineers, depending on the complexity and scope of the project.

Organizational structure:The organizational structure for the development of this system  can be complex. It could include different teams or departments for different aspects of the project, such as the app development team, the VR technology team, the logistics team (for
innovations like book delivery), the R&D team, etc. Each team would have its own leaders. , developers, designers and other personnel needed for their specific task.
Integration of technologies: The integration of different technologies such as VR, cloud systems, mobile applications and robots requires thorough testing to ensure compatibility and functionality.
Massive traffic can lead to difficulties in scaling the infrastructure, especially if cloud services or other technologies that depend on third-party resources are used.

The introduction of new functionalities such as online book lending or the use of VR technology may expose the system to a greater risk of security threats and require additional data protection measures.
Onboarding new users to the system may require additional training to ensure users fully understand the new functionalities and technologies.
Innovative technologies such as VR devices or robots require regular maintenance to ensure reliability and functionality.
The introduction of new functionalities may require adaptation of the organizational structure and employee roles in order to ensure effective customer support and system maintenance.

Some innovations such as VR books or borrowing via an application may require time for users to adapt and accept new technologies, especially if they are used to the traditional way of borrowing books.

Ensuring a high quality user experience is critical to the success of the system. Technical issues, a poorly designed user interface, or a lack of support can negatively impact user experience and satisfaction.
It is important to establish clear communication with users and library staff during the process of introducing new functionalities in order to reduce resistance to change and ensure support.
A willingness to adapt and develop iteratively is key to successfully managing change and responding to user feedback and market needs.

Cooperation of different parts of the organization is required, from the technical teams that develop the system to the operational teams that provide support to users. It will also be important to regularly assess and adjust the strategy to ensure successful innovation and change management.

System users: Cooks - responsible for preparing meals. They have access to recipes, raw materials and kitchen, appliances. Waiters - manage guests' orders, communicate with chefs and serve meals.
Restaurant Managers - Oversee the entire system, manage inventory, staff, and finances.
System functionalities:Order management - waiters enter guests' orders into the system, which forwards them to the chefs.

Inventory and supplies - managers keep track of food supplies and the necessary ingredients for preparing meals. Recipes and meal preparation - chefs access recipes, use them to prepare meals and record progress.
Communication - waiters and chefs communicate through the system to ensure the correct preparation and delivery of meals.
Bills and billing - the system generates bills for guests based on the meals ordered.

System is stuctured from Database - contains information about recipes, supplies, customers and orders. Kitchen appliances - the physical part of the system consisting of ovens, stoves, microwave ovens, etc., User interface - an application used by users.(1st application for a waiter the interface that displays the menu from the database, i.e. the dishes on it and the invoices of the finished orders, and on the other hand sends the meal order and payment confirmation,- 2nd application for chefs an interface that displays existing orders from the database, the stock status and sends information that the dish is ready, the newly created stock status after using it - 3rd application for managers an interface that displays invoices from the database and sends financial statements and Servers - computer devices that enable communication between users and the database.
Guest orders - Waiters enter order details into the system.
Meal preparation status - Chefs update the meal preparation status in the system.
Inventory and Ingredient List - Managers enter inventory information into the system and the system automatically updates the ingredient list based on current inventory.
Recipes - Chefs enter or update recipes in the system.
Financial data - Managers enter financial data into the system. The system provides managers with detailed financial reports.

Order status - The system provides updated information about the order status to waiters and guests. List of required ingredients - The system provides chefs with a list of ingredients needed to prepare a dish.
Inventory Reports - The system provides managers with reports on current inventory.
Dishes - Chefs prepare dishes according to recipes and orders, and then these dishes are served to guests.
Bills - The system generates bills for guests based on the dishes ordered.

The system contains sensitive information about users, orders, recipes and finances. You must ensure that this information is protected from unauthorized access, theft, loss or damage. You must also comply with legal regulations on privacy protection and data security.

Integration with other systems - the system must be able to communicate with other systems that are relevant to your business, such as systems for online reservations, food delivery, card payments, tax services, etc. You must ensure that these systems are compatible, reliable and uptodate .

The system must be easy and intuitive to use by your users, such as chefs, waiters and managers. You need to ensure that the system is fast, stable and error-free. You must also ensure that the system is adaptable to the different needs, preferences and situations of your users.

The system must be able to monitor and respond to changes and trends in the restaurant industry. You need to ensure that your system is in line with best practices, standards and expectations of your guests and partners. You also need to ensure that your system is
unique, creative and attractive to your target market.

The main problem this project seeks to solve is the inconvenience and inefficiency associated with conventional packet collection processes. From long lines at post offices to missed delivery attempts, the current system often fails to keep pace with the fast-paced demands of modern life. Additionally, problems such as package theft and misdelivery further exacerbate the frustrations experienced by both
consumers and couriers. This problem is tried to be solved by the implementation of packet machines. Paketomat is a smart package locker that automates the process of picking up packages. When the
package arrives, the courier staff enters the mobile phone number and places the package in a secure locker, the recipient is immediately notified via a text message with a password and can go to the locker to collect their package at any time that suits them.

Paketomat is an automated system designed to simplify the package collection process for consumers. Its functionality includes a number of features and components, each of which ensures efficiency, safety and ease of use.

Paketomat implements a user interface, which consists of a touch screen or an interactive panel. This interface serves as the primary point of interaction for consumers, guiding them through the package download process with clear instructions. Users can enter relevant information such as their unique identification code or order number to securely access their packages

To ensure the integrity of the package download process, the package machine includes robust authentication and security measures. Users can be asked to verify ownership through various means, such as biometric scans, PIN codes or digital signatures, thus preventing unauthorized access to their packages. Advanced encryption techniques and secure communication protocols protect sensitive data transmitted during the retrieval process, reducing the risk of interception or tampering.

Paketomat is connected to existing logistics networks and platforms, facilitating the seamless transfer of package information and tracking data. Use high speed internet connection and services cloud-based to synchronize real-time package status updates, enabling users to easily monitor the progress of their deliveries. Also, in order to ensure optimal performance and reliability, the vending machine has built-in diagnostic tools and remote monitoring capabilities. This enables remote troubleshooting and software updates, reducing the need for on-site maintenance visits and minimizing service interruptions.

In accordance with sustainable practices, the vending machine is designed with environmental issues in mind. Energy-efficient components and energy management systems reduce energy consumption and carbon footprint. Recyclable materials and environmentally friendly manufacturing processes are used wherever possible, ensuring minimal environmental impact throughout the machine's life cycle.

Developing such a system would require a multidisciplinary team of engineers, including software developers, hardware engineers, UX/UI designers, system architects, and quality assurance specialists. The size of the engineering team would depend on the scope and timeline of the project, as well as the expertise required

The organizational structure of the development team may include: Project Managers - Oversee overall project planning, resource allocation, and schedule management, Engineering Managers - responsible for coordinating the efforts of various engineering teams and ensuring alignment with project goals,  Cross-functional teams that focus on specific aspects of the system, such as software development, hardware design, user experience and integration, Quality assurance and testing teams responsible for verifying system functionality, performance and security, Support and maintenance teams responsible for continuous system monitoring,
updates and customer support

With a large number of users or during periods of high demand, the system must be designed to efficiently scale and handle increased traffic. This may include deploying redundant hardware components for load balancing and failover, optimizing software algorithms for performance, and implementing dynamic resource allocation strategies. Capacity monitoring and planning would be key to predicting and mitigating potential issues that may affect service availability.

During periods of high demand for the vending machine service, such as holidays or promotional events, the organization should have mechanisms in place to dynamically scale resources, adjust staffing levels accordingly, and prioritize critical tasks. Customer support teams would be key to responding to customer queries, resolving issues quickly and ensuring a positive customer experience during periods of high demand.

Security alarm: Sensor in case of a violent attempt to open the locker with the package. Triggering of the alarm after the application of a certain illegal force on the cabinet.
Humidity and temperature sensor: This information can be used to ensure that packages are stored in optimal conditions, especially for items that are sensitive to temperature or humidity.

Predictive Maintenance: Using BD analytics to predict equipment failures, maintenance needs and performance degradation based on historical data and machine learning models. Implementation of a predictive maintenance strategy to plan maintenance activities more effectively, minimize downtime and optimize equipment life

An industrial control system is a complex structure consisting of several key components such as hardware, software, people, data, and network components. Although each of these components is crucial to the functionality of the system, and has its own set of vulnerabilities and protection methods, the network component, by expanding the system and connecting to the outside world, becomes the most vulnerable part of the ICS.
specific protocols used in the industrial environment suffer in difference in protocols and their incompatibility
these protocols are very vulnerable from a security perspective and until recently, data sent via them was not encrypted
manufacturers prefer their own protocol, but at the Ethernet level the situation is different because the same hardware can implement different Ethernet protocols

these protocols were created as internal solutions at the level of individual companies, and their use is tied to the hardware of the same manufacturer. For such an application that is explicitly closed within the factory premises, data protection was not a priority.

it is possible that key data for process control is not forwarded from the controller (PLC) to the user interface (HMI), and the operator is misled about the current state of the process and does not react when necessary.
it is necessary to emphasize the importance of preserving data integrity in specific conditions such as the production process
It is generally known that intangible data can easily disappear or be compromised. Therefore, an updated backup copy has always been the basic measure for protecting its integrity.

However, in the domain of process control, this data does not only refer to common documentation such as diagrams, schemes, instructions, procedures, log files (alarm history, event history) etc. In a continuous production process, data is exchanged between various field devices, controllers and HMI interfaces, depending on the type of process, at high speed, and this involves a large amount of data that is crucial for maintaining process continuity. In the event of an interruption, it is difficult to ensure that the interrupted industrial process continues smoothly as soon as possible, even if all other elements are preserved. procedure for returning various virtual copies of software (Virtual machine) will be fully successful in a short time only if it includes "golden records". It is a kind of data image of the current state of the process that can be regenerated in an instant. Of course, this is only possible if such a set of data can be successfully collected and stored in real time. In this sense, flawless network functionality is key to significantly saving process recovery time.

IIoT enables the transfer of key information directly to the network (communication infrastructure), which greatly increases the level of data availability and the possibility of analyzing them in real time.

The basic philosophy of IIoT is based on the premise that smart devices are far better than humans when it comes to retrieving data, analyzing it in real time, and noticing important information important for quick and precise interventions in the system. The above has significant potential in the domain of quality control, sustainable development (sustainable and green practices), predictive maintenance (predictive maintenance), electricity distribution. energy (energy management, smart city), supply chain traceability and overall supply chain efficiency, etc

investment in process industry, energy, transport, logistics, and infrastructure has quadrupled compared to 2015. With such a rapid growth in investments, it is logical that the IIoT will have an increasing impact on the stability of industrial processes.
due to the specific nature of smart devices with advanced communication capabilities, the pressure on the security of the ICS network component is even greater
An IIoT network usually consists of an extremely large number of small switching devices (embedded devices) with a long lifespan which makes them very reliable.

Some of the IIoT devices do not have any possibility of updating, and it is necessary to carefully and carefully approach the selection of such devices (the number of which can reach several thousand) and their inclusion in the existing production network.
IIoT devices that are becoming critical points of attack, and that from a network that until now was considered safe if it was isolated from the corporate network

Although the security of industrial control systems is a comprehensive issue, it is necessary to not only recognize its complexity, but also certain differences between individual functional units within the system in relation to the time period that was available for security issues.
Functional safety assessment is a well-established practice in process automation. These assessments focus on random hardware failures or system software errors (such as omissions or errors in code).

cybersecurity risks (cyber risk) it is necessary to conduct a cybersecurity assessment and a cybersecurity risk assessment. Functional safety standards are now beginning to require a cybersecurity risk assessment (Control engineering, issue 03-2017)
Every Industrial Control System in a broad sense has certain weaknesses depending on its configuration and purpose
The size and branching of the system is also one of the factors that affect security. The larger the system, the greater the probability of an error.

the size of the system is usually associated with various legacy subsystems that are often outdated, but to some extent integrated, which often represents an additional critical element in terms of security.
Weak network architecture in terms of security.(system vulnerability)
Passwords are not encrypted in transit.(system vulnerability)
Network device configurations are not properly stored or backed up.(system vulnerability)
Passwords for accessing network devices are not changed regularly.(system vulnerability)
There are no data access control lists (Access Control Lists)(system vulnerability)
Poorly and misconfigured network security devices. (no defined routes on firewalland route(system vulnerability)
Lack of redundancy for critical parts of the network.(system vulnerability)
Inadequate physical protection of network equipment.(system vulnerability)
Danger of overheating of network equipment (system vulnerability)
Open access for staff to critical network components. (system vulnerability)
Allowed access to the system via USB keys and similar media.(system vulnerability)
Undefined access control. (system vulnerability)
The firewall does not exist or is incorrectly configured. (system vulnerability)
The network at the OT level is used for inadequate traffic (web browsing, e-mail) (system vulnerability)
Network services used at the OT level are not located within the ICS (DHCP, DNS,etc.
There is no security monitoring of the network at the ICS level.
inadequate firewall and router log files make it difficult to monitor network events
Inadequate authentication between client and AP (access point).
Inadequate data protection between client and AP(access point).

Some fundamental shortcomings in systems security are the result of an unprofessional approach and lack of knowledge of security in network systems. This is difficult to correct without the additional involvement of IT experts of the appropriate profile.
Unfortunately, awareness of the need for specific expertize and knowledge at the management level often does not exist until a critical situation arises.

Cyber risk is generally considered a function of three variables: threat, system vulnerability, and consequence. In the domain of cybersecurity, a threat is an external initiating event that aims to destabilize a system. Vulnerability is a specific weakness in a system that allows a threat to be realized, while a consequence is the undesired outcome of a realized threat.
To begin evaluating the system, it is necessary to analyze the network communication in order to understand how the network is structured and what the data flow is like (data flow).
it is necessary to analyze the protocols used, and the possible existence of communication with protocols that should not be in use, or at least should not be used between certain devices.

It is necessary to divide the system into logical zones so that the system can be better analyzed and more efficient protection can be applied at the level of individual zones, and communication between zones can be limited.

A Cyber risk assessment is a very good way to familiarize management with the current situation in order to plan future funding needs. "Most organizations want to understand what the real cyber risks are.

until the beginning of this century was partly shaped by the lack of statistical data on the cybersecurity of industrial control systems. The reason for this is the relatively short period of time that is, a short history of documented incidents in IT security before 2000. "A large number of organizations are very reluctant to report a security incident because they see it as a potential embarrassment. In fact, many organizations have denied the existence of cyber attack risks on industrial systems at all.(Byres, Eric; "The myths and the facts behihd cyber security risks for industrial control systems", 2013

According to the data from various sources, it is obvious that the source of threats to ICS has changed significantly, that is, the external source has more than doubled. Such a change can be partially explained by the entry of Windows OS into industrial plants, and the integration of TCP/IP protocols into ICS.

there are many entry points for secutity threads into today's SCADA, i.e. ICS systems, and it is not possible to focus the protection of such systems exclusively on the
Internet access point.

The brewing process consists of many interrelated stages such as malting, mashing, garnishing, brewing, cooling, fermentation, maturation, filtration and packaging. Each stage depends on the correct performance of the previous stage. The quality and characteristics of the raw materials (water, barley, hops, yeast) interact and affect the final product. A small change in one part of the system (eg changing the type of hops) can significantly affect the taste of the beer.

The fermentation process is non-linear as the rate of fermentation can increase exponentially depending on temperature and sugar concentration. Small changes in conditions can lead to big ones change in outcome. Quality control,we check, control and test the beer in all stages production process.
We use high-quality raw materials in sustainable processes that are led and supervised by qualified and experienced experts.

The emergent behaviour of the production process is reflected through Taste and Aroma: The final taste and aroma of beer is not a simple sum of individual ingredients, but the result of complex chemical reactions and interactions that occur during the entire production process. Consistency: The consistent taste of beer in large batches is the result of precise control and adjustment of all interdependent processes.

Recipe Adjustment: Breweries often adjust their recipes and processes based on feedback from previous batches and changes in raw materials. This ability to adapt is essential to maintain quality and meet market demands.

Technological Innovations: The introduction of new technologies and methods (such as advanced sensors and automation) enables breweries to quickly adapt to changes in production conditions and market demands.
Changing Conditions: Brewery production conditions, such as temperature and humidity, can change over time, requiring constant monitoring and adjustment to maintain quality.
Market Demands: Breweries must dynamically adapt to changing consumer preferences and regulatory requirements, which further adds to the complexity of the system.

Machine operators operate and maintain automated equipment, overseeing every step of the production process. Quality controllers conduct analyzes and ensure that each step of the process meets the required quality standards. Technical Staff, Engineers and technicians responsible for maintenance and calibration of automated systems and sensors.

Production managers are responsible for the overall coordination of the production process, including planning, monitoring and optimization. Quality Managers develop and implement strategies to ensure product quality and consistency. Logistics Managers plan and coordinate the procurement of raw materials and the distribution of finished products.

Scientists and Engineers are working on developing new recipes, fermentation techniques and improving existing production processes. Data analysts analyze data collected during production to optimize processes and  improve product quality.
Entire factory system should secure Consistency of quality, appearance, smell, taste. Safety, quality of beer, integrity of packaging.
Entire factory system should secure Precision of delivered output, e.g. taste of beer or cookie.
Entire factory system should secure  factory Efficiency, by reduction of loss of raw materials, process optimization, reduction of production time, reduction of costs.
Entire factory should secure Transparency, in product information across the factory, access to quality data from all factory divisions, communication with consumers, certificates and standards.
Entire factory should secure Adaptability ensuring process flexibility, quick reaction to external changes, fast integration of new technologies

Manufacturing: The system should have solid procedures and control points throughout the manufacturing process to ensure consistency in each batch of product. This includes strict monitoring of the recipe, mixing, fermentation, filtering, bottling and packaging processes

Quality Control: This function is essential to ensure consistency of product quality. The system should have mechanisms for checking the quality of raw materials, monitoring the production process and testing finished products to ensure that each product meets quality standards.

Storage and logistics: The system should have built-in mechanisms for proper storage of finished products in order to preserve their quality and freshness. It should also enable efficient logistics to deliver products to end users in optimal condition.
Equipment maintenance: Regular maintenance of equipment and systems is essential to ensure continuous operation and prevent any problems that could affect product quality.
Communication with users: The system should enable communication with end users to collect feedback on product quality, but also to provide user support and product information.
Monitoring and reporting: Monitoring key performance indicators and generating reports gives managers insight into how the system is performing and enables identification of areas for improvement.
Production capacity: A brewery may reach maximum production capacity, which leads to the need to expand capacity, acquire additional equipment and hire additional staff.
Product quality: Rapid growth can affect the consistency of product quality due to system overload and possible reductions in storage time.
Distribution: More efficient logistics and distribution channels are needed to meet greater market needs.
Excess inventory: A brewery may have excess inventory that is not being sold, which can lead to increased storage costs and possible product spoilage.

Financial losses: A decrease in income can threaten the financial stability of the company, which can result in a reduction in the number of employees or a decrease in investment in equipment and technology.
Equipment maintenance: Equipment may be underutilized, which may increase maintenance costs per unit of product.

Depending on how the change in the number of users occurred, companies can in some way fight against such situations, such as placing new products on the market or improving marketing. and working on the rebranding of some products, such as changing the appearance of the packaging in order to better represent the product or, for example, to try to get closer to its largest group of users.

precise production planning is needed to adapt to seasonal variations in demand, to achieve flexible employment of seasonal workers and contracting of raw material suppliers to reduce costs in periods of
lower demand.

the technological progress of the company is important, because then the company can adapt much more easily to changes in production requirements. It is much cheaper to pay for the maintenance of a robot than to pay for surplus labor that appears in the off-season.
Lack of raw materials: Problems in the supply of barley, hops or yeast can lead to a reduction in production and changes in the recipe.
Price increase: Rising raw material prices can increase production costs, which may require beer prices to increase or margins to decrease.
Quality of raw materials: Variability in the quality of raw materials can affect the consistency of taste and quality of beer.
Labor shortages: Difficulties in finding skilled labor can slow production and increase the cost of training new employees.
Labor costs: Increases in minimum wages and labor costs can affect total production costs, requiring process optimization to maintain profitability.

robots replacing human labor enable greater resistance to such cases. On the other hand they require a large financial investment, which sometimes does not pay off, and problems surrounding the integration of such systems into another complex system.
Energy resources: Increases in energy prices can affect production costs, especially in energy-intensive processes such as cooking and cooling.
Water: during the production of beer, there is also a great dependence on quality and available water

A brewery system can be very sensitive to external changes, but with the right strategies and adjustments, it can increase its resilience and maintain stable production and product quality. Technological Innovation is important because the introduction of advanced technologies and automation increases efficiency and reduces dependence on the workforce.
Requirements specification: Precisely defining the requirements for a new system can be challenging due to the complexity of manufacturing processes and the diverse needs of different departments
Integration of existing systems: New solutions must be integrated with existing systems, which may require adjustments and additional resources.
Challenge is Monitoring technological progress: Keeping pace with the latest technological trends and selecting appropriate technologies to improve production efficiency and quality.
Implementing innovative ways to automate processes can require significant investment and employee training
It is necessary to maintain the system continuously and not only when a problem arises, also in maintenance now and its improvement.
Regular maintenance: Constant maintenance of equipment and software is required to ensure smooth production.
Software and equipment updates: Introducing regular updates of software solutions to improve the functionality and security of systems and equipment
Connecting different systems: Ensuring compatibility between new and existing systems can be challenging and requires expertise in software and hardware integration.
Data Integration: Ensuring data integrity when transferred between different systems to avoid data loss.
Process change (eg integration of a new system) requires employees to adapt to new processes and technologies, and may require extensive training and adjustment time.

In the integration of new systems, it is also very good to promote a culture of innovation and talk to system users for easier acceptance of changes within the company in order to facilitate the transition to new systems.
The time required for new users (employees) to be able to use the system independently and efficiently should be as short as possible.
Ease of use: New systems must be intuitive and easy to use to ensure a high level of acceptance among users.
User support: Ensuring adequate support for users when introducing new functionalities and users, including training and technical support.

The development, maintenance and integration of systems in a brewery presents a series of challenges that require careful planning and management. The key to success lies in understanding the needs of the company, choosing appropriate technologies, continuous monitoring and optimization of the process, and ensuring it adequate support and training for all system users.
some processes require employees entirely and their speed and attention affect the speed and quality of production, while some are fully automated by robots
the employee had to spend some time to even get to the control panel where he had to start every few minutes or stop different processes.
Each sub-process is physically separate and requires workers to manually open and close pipes
the sub-processes within the real factory context do not have any mutual communication because they do not even have a complete physical connection where one could affect the other

Due to the automatic disconnection, there is no central system where data could be collected and thus the cloud function is not used, there is one person who supervises all sub-processes and tests, and we can consider her as a central system for monitoring all subprocesses, which is very inefficient because it is a production factory and quite large, so a lot of time is wasted just moving through that factory
Introduction of AI"brain" of the device can improve for additional speed and precision of manufacturing operations.

A BEER PALLET STORAGE MONITORING SYSTEM an IoT based technology innovation. The pallets would be equipped with a sensor that would record the time when the beer was placed on the pallet and in what quantities. Also, each pallet would have a GPS locator. This system would provide forklift drivers with information about where the pallet is, what beer is on it, the quantity and the date it was filled. Ultimately, the system helps to ensure that the beer that was made first is picked up first so that beer does not stay in the warehouse for a long time, and speeds up the process of loading beer onto trucks. Each pallet is equipped with a GPS locator and an RFID tag. As pallets are moved within the factory, their location is constantly updated via GPS tracking devices. RFID readers at strategic points (egwarehouse entrance/exit) check IDs and pallet movement. GPS and RFID data are sent to the central data processing system, which processes the data and monitors the location and status of each pallet. Forklift drivers use mobile devices or tablets on which they receive instructions on where to place or retrieve pallets based on the 'first in, first out' principle. . The system alerts drivers if an older pallet needs to be moved before a new one, ensuring proper stock rotation.

IoT makes it possible to analyze and collect a large amount of data through various sensors in various plants, by implementing a program for collecting and processing this data and analyzing it, it is possible to detect possible irregularities in the process production. In this way, it would be possible to react in time to the detected error, which ultimately increases productivity and reduces production costs. IoT sensors installed in different stages of the production process (e.g. brewing beer, fermentation, packaging) collect data on parameters such as temperature, pressure and flow rates. The data is transferred to data storage systems, which are usually located on cloud platforms. Big Data analytical platforms process the collected data. Machine learning and artificial intelligence algorithms analyze data to predict potential problems in the manufacturing process. Control panels allow workers in the plant to closely monitor the production process, enabling quick responses to the appearance of any irregularities. By analyzing historical and real-time data, equipment failures can be predicted to avoid unexpected downtime. Ultimately, this system leads to an increase in productivity and a reduction in costs.

one of the main problems that appears in the real factory context is the training of new employees in the production process. The implementation of emerging technologies enables learning in an interactive way and enables participants to gain an easier idea of how things work in the production process. By using augmented reality, participants can practice work activities in real time, at their own pace and without pressure from customers, managers and other expectations. AR allows new employees to practice tasks without the risk of injury or jeopardizing the business process. Augmented reality implementation for employee education includes wearable augmented reality glasses. These glasses allow employees to see digital information and virtual objects alongside physical world objects, enabling interaction with simulated environments and tasks. In this way, AR would enable the design of interactive training scenarios and the simulation of beer production processes. It would also make it possible to track employee progress on the effectiveness of the training program and identify areas for improvement.

one of the planned innovations is the implementation of a single line for filling glass and aluminum packaging. By using CPS, it is recognized whether it is glass or tin packaging and thus the filling method is automatically adjusted. The technology required would include computer vision to recognize packaging and robotic arms and conveyors to handle different types and sizes of bottles. The implementation of Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) automatically recognizes the type of packaging and adjusts the filling method accordingly. As the packaging enters the filling line, sensors (optical, RFID, barcode scanners) identify whether it is glass or aluminum packaging. Based on the identified package type, the control system adjusts the filling parameters. For glass bottles, slower filling speeds and reduced pressure may be included to prevent breakage. Higher filling speeds and different pressure settings can be used for aluminum cans. Actuators and smart filling nozzles make the necessary adjustments in real time, can adjust filling speed, volume and pressure to suit glass or aluminum packaging. The system continuously monitors the charging process using sensors and provides feedback. The interface provides alerts and
notifications about system performance, maintenance needs, and potential problems.

complexity is actually the relationship between workers and workers and workers and machines. Then, if everything is in order, put the cookies on the baking sheet.

Standardized processes; quality control (baking, mixing, etc.), hygiene, adherence to rules, safety at work.
Trained workers.
Customer feedback; they take good thoughts from customers and set them as the thought of the day, and give away a gift package as a reward.

An inside view for complex systems development is needed because when you look from outside everything looks beautiful, meaningful and easy to implement. However, when you visit an real case scenario and talk with personel and see all the process interactions then you realize its complexity and how difficult it may be to addess all the requirements for its technological evolution

Implementation of new technology also depend of the context where it is planned. While implementing complex systems the real factory visit is important because you can see interaction with other processes and you can realize some cases that you can not even think of in the classroom. E.g. if you imagine a robotic arm working alone you will think idealistically, however, when you come to the real factory you start thinking about what would happen if there is a break, or if there are some maintenance levels, that the reliability of that hand is not 100%, that it can become obsolete, that these are some kind of real problems.

A complex system is a unique whole that works, works, works, but has many aspects, many small units that are independent, that form it. That is important to understand when you aim to improve the whole system behaviour.
A structured approach to identify various aspects of complex systems, to throw out unnecessary information that do not belong in the complex system itself, and to structure my vision better.

Certain process constraints or boundaries within process variations are impossible to determine solely from an office environment. Each factory context may have unique parameter calibration values, such as the need to tune the velocity of a robotic arm to suit the specific factory conditions and acceptable movement trajectories that can be determined only from the real context.

an awareness that there can be stoppages or disruptions in the working of particular processes, and when the product line is continuous, these stoppages may have consequences for other associated processes in the production line.

Maintaining physical equipment and managing software upgrades are crucial, as some physical equipment may wear out over time. It is important to carefully monitor and maintain physical equipment as well as update associated software to keep the system running efficiently.
the existing factory technology is not yet ready to support such innovations,
proper engineering should consider legacy or regulatory concerns in the particular context of that factory,
The financial aspects of the company and its business goals often do not fully recognize the technological benefits.
The current factory culture and workers' technological awareness may not be adequately prepared to support the innovations we proposed.
Workers are reluctant to embrace technological improvements in factory processes because they do not perceive the benefits of such innovations.
Workers may be apprehensive about losing their jobs due to factory automation and process improvements.

The student reflection highlights the need to improve technological awareness and skills among students in elementary and secondary schools. This is crucial that we reform our eudation system as automation and AI will require technologically skilled workers and personnel. While some repetitive tasks may be automated, new competencies will be required to thrive in the evolving job market.

The analysis also highlighted the impact of company scale on innovation capability. Larger companies may be more suitable for implementing more substantial improvements, while the scalability of the company influences its innovation readiness and appropriateness. It is important to be aware that different company sizes exist, and certain innovations may not be suitable for smaller companies due to their scale. Additionally, companies may have varying criteria for their software requirements.
Furthermore, the analysis highlighted the importance of a participatory change strategy, emphasizing the need to actively engage stakeholders in the innovation process.
Students expressed concern about software failure and its potential consequences, including damage to the company's reputation, financial impact, security issues, and even threats to human life.

Companies often have a limited understanding of the uncertain risk dimensions encompassing their factory business, market, and operations during the timeframe of factory innovation acceptance and subsequent adoption of new working conditions.

The information students could gather from the internet differed significantly from the insights they gained during the actual company visit regarding the factory processes and potential requirements.

The gradual, scalable introduction to the factory visit was a good learning approach. At the beginning, the presentation on complex systems and discussions of imaginary cases and their challenges left us confused about the key learning points. However, when we then switched to defining a real small-scale application, with the support of a structured guideline, we struggled to understand what we should address in each question of the seminar structure. But when we came to the actual factory visit, the awareness of the key learnings and how to address the questions within the seminar enabled us to better address the key learning points within the real factory environment and to ask the questions that we needed to address in our seminar.

If we had only been presented with all the key learnings from the beginning and were expected to remember those points, I am afraid we would not have been able to truly understand the problems of complexity or learn how to effectively address them. The scalable, gradual introduction to the key learnings, including concrete case studies and interactions with other students (economy) as well as with workers from the real-world environment, forced us to grapple with the complexities firsthand and consider potential problems, solutions, and consequences. This hands-on, immersive approach would have been difficult to achieve through solely theoretical presentations and discussions within the classroom setting.

If we had only been presented with all the key learnings from the beginning, we would have been lost during the factory visit and unable to write a seminar that was directly related to the key learnings of addressing complex systems. That is why it was useful to scale the learning process, starting with mini case studies before the actual factory visit. If we had not worked through the seminar structure on a small-scale example, we probably would not have captured the key learnings, even though the technology guide within the factory covered many of the problems that we later incorporated into our seminar writings. This structured approach also enabled us to ask more relevant questions during the factory visit.

Visit to the real world where the software is deployed is beneficial because you can see how small system innovations or units can impact the overall complex system behavior. I realized that comprehending the possible consequences is not a straightforward endeavor, as not only technical but also social and economic dimensions can have a significant influence.

The structured instructions with guiding questions made it easier for us to develop requirements for the analysed system because we did not waste time theorizing or rejecting irrelevant considerations, which streamlined the writing process. The instructions directed us and helped structure our reflections on how to effectively observe complex systems.

Structured instructions would be helpful for me in the future when dealing with complex systems. Providing a clear framework and asking targeted questions is crucial to capturing key learnings and avoiding getting lost in the intricacy of the topic.

We were not initially aware of the various emerging technologies, but the brief presentation provided us with the opportunity to propose numerous innovations that could significantly improve our mini case application.
Visit to the real context where software is deployed is benefitial for software developers because there you are able to see how software interacts with other systems, machines, and people.

The complex system is a continuous process with numerous internal and external factors that can influence the flow of processes, their speed, and the potential consequences for the market, products, company reputation, and the future of the company's production.

Professionalism as a responsibility to innovate should become a global strategy, and with this goal, the transformation of education should happen. The question of technology investment and the sharing of responsibility should become a consensus between the economy and technology, not a stumbling block.

Companies are primarily focused on driving product innovations that they can bring to market, rather than technology innovations that could improve their efficiency and effectiveness. It seems that workers and managers do not fully understand the potential benefits that new technologies could bring to their factory business, while product innovations are generally more straightforward to calculate and predict.

People's attitudes towards new technology are a key prerequisite for technology transformation. To enable this, people should be upskilled in technological aspects across all disciplines, such as chemistry and economics. Additionally, in manufactories, a new role focused solely on technology innovation should be introduced.

Every software developer who works on complex systems should spend time within the context of that system, interacting with the humans who work with it. Many aspects cannot be predicted based solely on imagination; they must be experienced through direct interaction with the system, as complex systems have dynamic operations that are difficult to describe even statically, let alone capture their full dynamics.

Workers who interact with complex systems understand the complexity of their dynamic operation and have experience dealing with malfunctions and faulty cases, where human intuition and quick action are crucial to avoid serious consequences. This is likely the main reason why they are skeptical that software can replace humans in every aspect. Therefore, their firsthand experience is of key importance for the adequate design and modeling of factory innovations and transformations.

Introducing innovations in complex systems can have a significant impact on the workers who interact with machines in factories. From the company visit, I realized that workers are often critical of new technologies. Their competencies are of key importance for the operation and transformation of factories.

The factories' operations can have significant impacts on ecology and sustainability, so the software responsible for managing the physical machinery is of key importance to achieve these environmental goals and ensure the factories' operations are ecologically and sustainably acceptable.

My impression is that workers often have a negative attitude towards new technologies because they are afraid for their jobs and do not fully understand the consequences of technological innovations. Additionally, they may not realize the need to upgrade their competencies to satisfy the new working conditions. Resistance to change is a normal process, but it requires adequate management to address these concerns.
For the future software engineering profession, it is important not only to understand emerging technologies but also to comprehend how the real context works, both in a static and dynamic manner.

Software developers need to understand the experiences and expectations of the people working with the systems we engineer, as well as their thought processes. We often fail to fully grasp the consequences our software may have on the actual factory, the dimensions of their operations, and the potential stakeholders involved.
Software developers must consider the legal, security, and ecological aspects of the system's interaction with its environment.
Innovating complex systems, such as manufacturing, requires a multidimensional and interdisciplinary approach from various viewpoints to effectively specify requirements.

Real industrial context experience is hardly transferred to other people by storytelling and presenting. The real industrial context should be experienced by every student and person involved in engineering complex systems.
Factory innovations have numerous consequences such as peoples education, additional time and money for education, financial and risk aspects of technology transformation, and workers upskilling

There is a huge difference when the developer is developing code within a classroom and in a real industrial context. Numerous aspects can not be imagined from the classroom environment. It is easier to identify limitations, important problems, and prioritization of issues.

The importance of testing for software control is the need for some document that would define what and how some software should satisfy requirements before its acceptance within so complex environments.

The factory visit was very interesting, we had the opportunity to see a very complex production process and we had the opportunity to see how AI is implemented within the production process we never seen it before and heard about some experiences of workers working with AI implemented in manufacturing

Company visits enabled me to understand peoples side working with complex systems that we did not take into account from the classroom and could not imagine all the challenges people may face with working in such environments.

Visiting real factory is beneficial because we see how emerging technologies are implemented within real complex systems, what problems the people working with these systems have and how they plan to improve themselves in the future

We got an idea of ??what a complex system means (it looks much simpler in the classroom environment), there each of the machines is a complex system by itself, maybe it would be better if it were a simpler example because I got lost from the beginning to end, we saw in the factory problems that is difficult to imagine in a class, we could assess the challenges more than in a class, it is easier to communicate challenges in person with workers from the factory context, even though the person who guided us told us about most of the challenges when you see it in person and only when something is implemented, you only then really understand the problems better than in theory.

Probably the course could be done without a physical visit to the company but a physical visit is more etched in the memory, and direct contact with workers in their working environment allows asking questions and provides motivation to think about questions.

When you see a robotic arm integrated into the manufacturing process, you see that it is big, its strength and that development should be approached responsibly, it is not as simple as in theory. The question remains how to embed responsibility in those robotic hands (for example, to make a person trust that such a tool will not harm anyone) - it is necessary to test, and watch out for borderline cases, and possible accidents in factories.

the one who buys a robot should know that it is a robot and that there is nothing that is flawless, and are we ready to risk a collision - not all responsibility should be on the developer, there should be something on the owner and the user as well

The instructions for the specification of requirements were useful, and when I go to the factory I can see all the consequences of my requirements you look at those instructions in a completely different way when you define requirements for a factory as a complex system and when you define requirements for a simpler application that we can think of from the classroom environment. A visit to the factory is the best way to understand a real example of a complex system with a discussion with workers. For example, a Beach cabin versus skyscraper, it was an ok example of complex system, but only when we went to the factory we understand more aspects of the complex system.

I understood what you mean by complexity in the factory case study, but I couldn't explain some functions, or structure because I don't have enough knowledge about it. I could hardly apply modern principles and new technologies, i.e. innovations, because I didn't do that. The library case study was different because I could work out the functions of the system myself, new technologies helped me because I could significantly improve my functional requirements in the library. There I could recognize design principles. If you did not presented us new technologies, I would have made an ordinary library.

In the factory, I could see how important the financial and social aspects are when introducing new technologies. Even when we had totally crazy and innovative ideas, it was difficult to convince people that it would be useful for them.

In the factory, we could also see ecology in the conversation about dependence and clean water and the problem of waste disposal. The factory can also be a polluter, so you have to think about the filters...

I learned from the course that a complex system must be designed correctly and that the structure of the system must follow certain principles (e.g. even when there are skyscrapers, safety exits should be planned in case of danger, a sufficiently strong shaft),

In the software developer profession, there are some rules for writing code and they relate to responsible we write code so that others can inherit it from us (professionalism, clean code, design principles, modularity, ... the better the design is planned, the better it can be improved tomorrow).
I learn that learning new technologies can significantly improve the solution we will offer, and continuous education of new technologies is very important for software developers,

In the factory, I realized that the social aspect and financial aspects of the factory are very important for solving the application. A software developer must be aware of the needs of the factory and the people in it. I understand that the purpose of the course is to raise system engineer professional awareness. The course syllabus talks about complex systems and design principles. This could easily be verified through a test. But after these learning methods, I learned to look differently at the software development profession, the dimensions of sw developer responsibility - I could certainly suggest better software now. From this course I learned responsibility, socialization and technologies, different thinking on the application through the structure and on the design of the solution.

But after these learning methods, I learned to look differently at the software development profession, the dimensions of sw developer responsibility - I could certainly suggest better software now.
