The course is well planned, this is how to gradually enter the problem and each new case opened up something new for us. If it had all been said in one presentation through a lecture, I would not have learned so much.

What would be the laws and soft skills that should be learned at Universities for software developers? Through university students, professors should make us think. As our parents teach us personal and social responsibility, the same we learn here in the course for the professional responsibility. What should we pay attention to while developing sw - continuous learning, social aspect, economic aspect? This kind, of course, is ok, examples and communication - this interview is an important part of the course, it all comes together a bit, better than just reciting a slide if we had gone to the factory without the seminar, we certainly wouldn't have learned so much, the same without of this conversation, I wouldn't be so aware of what it has to do with each other.

Would you remember all those aspects if you came to the company tomorrow and started working. I think that this conversation will have an impact - I would never think that I have to go and ask an employee if they will accept it or not, I would only think about functionality and probably without the application of new technologies.

Questions such as the complex system, design principles, and aspects of responsibility. It is better to have a conversation one-on-one than in a group, even though it takes a lot of time, but not everyone could express their opinion in a group.

When AI is implemented, one must always think about a redundant system that will question AI decisions in other limits, for example, a robotic AI control arm and sensors that sense the environment and provide context information for limited movement. Who would be responsible for the wrong move of the robotic arm - for example, if it kills a man - perhaps the software developer could implement a redundant system to ensure the safety of the robotic arm. A security system needs to know the context of where that hand will come from and what that security means. This security is not protection from a hacker attack, but security from your software working properly in a given environment. Most likely, I wouldn't have remembered to implement AI protection if I applied AI in my products before this factory visit.

I had a problem in identifying the system structure because I did not know where to start, or how to define an abstract rule which would guide me through system structure definition. For example, What are all the roles in the system, i.e. librarian, then a separate system for searching, various views in the system I did not know how to combine into the same structure image. Finally, I depicted some structure and recognized the modules, but when I went to analyze the system in more detail, tried to apply the examples of good practices, and find design patterns I was not so sure if I understood everything correctly. The brewery factory was more complex, so it was harder to describe everything, although the woman talked a lot more. Waffles are a much simpler example. The structured approach to helped me because I was prepared on was required of me, so it was much easier to fill reports after the factory visits.

The problem with depicting system structure is to find the right level, things can be described deeply and shallowly. Well, find the right level  In the factory example, the factories are much more complex. There I took what they said and tried to insert it into the questions from the seminar. I didn't want to deepen the story further.

I was genuinely interested in the fact that we went to those factories, how they do it, what all the processes they have, how they cooperate, and also the problems of how the workers deal with them, how they share the money when they earn more, so I also saw that some companies maybe they don't even need to introduce so many new technologies.

The structured approach to factory helped me to better prepare for information collection, so then I might not have paid attention to some things that were required in the seminar and the woman in factory was talking. Well, maybe I wouldn't be able to write so much in 2 seminars. A lot of what was said there could be connected with the questions of the seminar.

The goal was to show a smaller and bigger factory. I remembered a lot more in the smaller one, and the second one was more complicated, so we had to go from object to object, so there was too much information for me.

How did you like what the people from economics did? It was great because we learned something from them and they learned something from us. I learned from them that there are different categories of companies, local small, large, international small, and large. And how to do strategic management. And that would be useful for me in my profession because I realized that not all companies want to implement all technologies at once, but that it depends on their market goal.

Concepts are hard to learn. That's boring. Open the standard, try to go through it, and define it for your application. None of the students did that. Today, you learn and get numerous small tools and make some small projects yourself, but you don't get the conceptual knowledge of how to look at it all and fit it into one story.
A responsible software developer has to perceive all meritorious aspects

Did you realize through this course that it is not important that software is only functioning? Yes, I saw the practice in the real factory and that opened my awareness of the domains of software quality.

One person who is risky has less responsibility and the other person thinks much more to reduce the risk.  We should know someone's behavior over time. Well, if one looks at all the Aspects of the system, one should emphasize all the Aspects that are meritorious. So a more responsive design would be one that looks at all situations.

What would be the professional core values? - knowledge?? what kind - at least some basis for the job applied for (eg frontend, backend, coding, design is important, technologies and programs) You mean mostly technological skills and are there any other skills? I think that's the most important thing.

Reflection through the course. What is the biggest benefit that you have learned? I hope that I will open my own company as soon as possible, so this visit to the factory was useful for me to see what it looks like, I prefer a small factory to see how it is organized as a family business and what is the attitude towards the workers, it opened my eyes some views I hadn't thought about. For example there are 12 workers, but there are always 11 because there is always someone on the annual leave - I learned a lot about business. The more processes there are, the more it means that you have to approach the problem strategically, how to divide the work, who has control over whom, what does that control mean, what are the control mechanisms, how would you divide the work among these people. Who would you hire, how would you divide these responsibilities when the process is continuous?

PyTkiner helped me to visualize the processes and structure of my application. However, it is could not be used to draw everything from reality. We were able to simulate part of reality through the computer. eg using the random function.

Where do you see the job of sw developer, what does it have to do with you? In a smaller factory, not really, but in a bigger factory (brewery), every machine has some software, so you need to maintain that software. Someone who has completed 5 years of computer science would probably need to do something like this. Why. Well, I've never encountered that bottle separation may be automatized with help of machine learning, I should learn about it.

What is the difference between a mini-case application (e.g. web application for an apartment) and software for automating part of some complex system like is in brewary? Correctness, whether the software works correctly, for example, to recognize a broken bottle in the bottle separation part of the factory process. The bottle can be chipped, but some sw can erase some dimensions and some shapes, but how to define what is acceptable and what is not? That would have to be defined for software developers, e.g. by the people who are responsible for factory process quality. A lot is unknown, and it is difficult to collect all the requirements, today ChatGPT can write code, but you need to set the requirements very well. Professionalism is needed where serious systems are developed. For a person to know how to operate such systems, a person needs to know how to solve problems, be creative.

What did you notice in the brewery? I noticed that they have a problem with moisture, that it will cause problems in their industry. What does that have to do with a computer science student. Well, if moisture gets through the device, then it would have an effect on the incorrect operation of the device. Then it could be a problem that this moisture affects the operation of the software.

Employees who work for a brewery have to focus on their job descriptions, job descriptions have to be clear minimising overlaps. Then the technology supporting their jobs have to be easy for workers in the brewery to understand and use. Less time will be needed for learning and improvement and for mistakes.
